IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: George Fox University, a Christ-centered community, prepares students spiritually, academically, and professionally to think with clarity, act with integrity, and serve with passion through both undergraduate & graduate educational programs of study for approximately 3.400 students.
IRS990.MissionDescription: To prepare students spiritually, academically, and professionally to think with clarity, act with integrity, and serve with passion through both undergraduate & graduate educational programs of study for approximately 3.400 students.
IRS990.Description: Quality undergraduate education programs in the humanities, sciences and professional studies with more than 40 majors

Activity2.Description: Quality Graduate education programs in the areas of Psychology, Counseling, Education, Business, & seminary inclduing 5 seminary degrees & 11 master's and doctoral degrees.

Activity3.Description: Athletic progamsa for Men & Women developing leadership & team-building skills including Baseball, Softball, Volleyball, Basketball, Track, Cross-country, Soccer, Golf and Tennis. (NCAA division 3)

ActivityOther.Description: SPS Adult education programs, Admissions, Student Life, Management & General, & Fundraising - everything else.

OtherSecurities.Description: Utah property helpd in common w/ other Univ.
Christian College Consortium fund - part ownership

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Art items are used in teaching, & the ancient manuscripts are part of an ongoing project to preserve ancient manuscripts for posterity and to provide the scanned documents for scholarship.
The university's endowment funds provide scholarship funds as well as operating revenue for specific programs.

Income tax status - The University is exempt from federal and state income taxes under the provisions of Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. However, income from certain activities not directly related to the University's tax-exempt purpose is subject to taxation as unrelated business income. Unrelated business income tax, if any, is insignificant and therefore, no tax provision has been made in the accompanying financial statements. In addition, the University qualifies for the charitable contribution deduction under Section 170(b)(1)(A) and has been classified as an organization that is not a private foundation under Section 170(b)(1)(A)(ii). The University recognizes the tax benefit from uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax positions will be sustained on examination by the tax authorities, based on the technical merits of the position. The tax benefit is measured based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized upon ultimate settlement. The University had no unrecognized tax benefits at June 30, 2010 and 2009. The University recognizes interest accrued and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as an administrative expense. During the years ended June 30, 2010 and 2009, the University recognized no interest and penalties. The University files an exempt organization income tax return and an unrelated business income tax return in the U.S. federal jurisdiction and a copy with the states of California, Idaho, Oregon and Washington. The appropriate state returns are also filed for any unrelated business income. With few exceptions, the University is no longer subject to U.S. federal or state/local income tax examinations by tax authorities for years before 2006.

Financial Aid is neeted with Tuition income on the audited financial statements. This adds the tuition associated with the Financial aid back to the income $17,515,415 less Cost of sales included on the income side fir inventory cost of Sales & Schedule T expenses $1,802,279.
Bookstore expenditures included in Cost of Sales and 990-T expenses

FundraiserActivityInformation.Activity: solicitation of estate planning, annuities and trusts

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: The philosophy of student aid is to provide access and choices to students who, without financial assistance, would not be able to attend an institution of higher learning. The Executive Director of Student Financial Services is responsible for establishing Institutional policy development surrounding the delivery of financial assistance. Policy development adheres to federal and state laws and regulations as well as to the mission of the University. When appropriate, Financial Aid policy is reported to and approved by the Vice President of Enrollment Services. These policy changes also involve the Vice President of Financial Affairs. The primary purpose of a collegiate financial aid program should be to provide financial assistance to accepted students who, without such aid, would be unable to attend that university. Each university has an obligation to assist in realizing the national goal of equality of educational opportunity. The University, therefore, should work with schools, community groups, and other educational institutions in support of this goal. Parents are expected to contribute according to their means, taking into account their income, assets, number of dependents, and other relevant information. Students themselves are expected to contribute from their own assets and earnings, including appropriate borrowing against future earnings. Need-based financial aid should be offered only after determination that the resources of the family are insufficient to meet the student's educational expenses. The amount of need-based aid offered should not exceed the amount needed to meet the difference between the student's total educational expenses and the family's resources. The amount and type of self-help expected from students should be related to the circumstances of the individual. In the assignment of funds to those students designated to receive financial aid, the largest amounts of total grant assistance should go to students with the least ability to pay. The university should review its financial assistance awards annually and adjust them, if necessary, to reflect changes in the financial needs of students and the expenses of attending the institution. The university has an obligation to inform students and parents of the financial aid renewal policies for enrolled students at the time of the initial offer of financial assistance. Because the amount of financial assistance awarded reflects the economic circumstances of students and their families as well as available funding, the university should refrain from any public announcement of the amount of aid offered and encourage students, their secondary schools, and others to respect the confidentiality of this information. Selection of students to receive financial aid will be made without regard to age, sex, race, color, religion, national origin, disability or marital status. Priority consideration for aid is given to students whose files are complete by March 1 of each year. The institution will package each student according to the matrix need assigned the student. This determination is made by the award year the student will enter. Once the matrix year is determined the student is awarded a percentage of his or her (FAFSA) need with federal, state and institutional aid. The student is then awarded Work-study, followed with Perkins loan, Stafford (subsidized or unsubsidized) loan and the PLUS loan. Aid is "frozen" from one year to the next. In extreme instances as defined by the SFS Office, the amount of grant money may be increased. Honors scholarships are awarded based on the high school GPA and either the SAT or ACT scores. Students will continue to receive the scholarship as long as a continuation cumulative GPA is maintained. Award letters are mailed to the student whenever there is a change to the financial aid award and the change affects federal or state awards.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: The university maintains a required residence for the president of the university in order to facilitate such entertaining as is required by the office and for the convenience of the university. Some of the ministers on staff allocate a portion of their income to housing allowance in accordance with the IRS code. A University Club membership is maintained for the current president of the universisty to enhance networking in the business community.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Financial Affairs office staff prepares the 990. It is reviewed by both the Assistant VP & VP for Financial Affairs before filing. The Board of Trustees Finance Committee reviews the 990 after it is filed at their next meeting.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: All employees & board of trustee members are required to complete a new conflict of Interest from each year. These records are maintained and monitored in the Human Resources department.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Key employee and top official salaries are reviewed & approved by the Board of Trustees after review of data from comparable schools.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Our conflict of interest policy is available on our website. We do not make public our financial statements except as required in Form 990 disclosures.

ReasonableCauseExplanation.Explanation: Extension of time for filing was accepted. Feb 15, 2011 is the new due date.
